Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi all,
 I am glad to share with you the results I got after running my dis=
tributed
genetic implementation on Frostbite Atari game.

Due to the limite=
d hardware resources I have (only available 36 CPU
cores),  I fixed the pop=
ulation size to only 1000 individuals.
I stopped the training after 100 gen=
erations because waiting to reach 1B
frames costs a lot of time. These 100 =
generations proceeded about 321402808
frames.
I saved  the Highest performi=
ng model every 50 generation:
At generation 50, the best model scored 4490 =
and at generation 100 the best
model scored 5350 which is considered a very=
 exciting result as far as I
know.

There is something that is not clear to=
 me:
I have followed the paper baselines for no-op operations but I noticed=
 that
the agent is not robust at random starts ( the median at generation 1=
00 was
180)
I am wondering if anyone could clarify this for me or tell me i=
f this
problem is also encountered in your implementation.

Thank you,
Best=
 regards,
=E1=90=A7

2018-05-30 9:46 GMT+01:00 Rihab Gorsane <rihab.gorsane=
@...>:

> Thank you Felipe,
>
> Best regards,
>
> 2018-05-30 0:19 G=
MT+01:00 Felipe Such felipe.such@... [neat] <
> neat@yahoogroups.com>:=

>
>>
>>
>> Hi Rihab,
>>
>> Feel free to reach out with any questions, we a=
re glad people are
>> interested on the paper and reproducing it's results.=

>> We are using NoFrameskip-v4. We follow the same preprocessing steps as
=
>> other methods (Example: https://github.com/openai/base
>> lines/blob/mas=
ter/baselines/common/atari_wrappers.py). We use the
>> accumulated reward (=
no discount factor, no clipping).
>> You are right on the 20k frames limit =
as it translates to 5k timesteps
>> after the frame skips.
>>
>> Best regar=
d,
>> Felipe
>>
>> On Tue, May 29, 2018 at 1:59 AM, Rihab Gorsane rihab.gor=
sane@...
>> [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Hi =
all,
>>>
>>> I've begun reproducing the DeepNeuroevolution paper in Pytorch=
. I've
>>> considered only the Atari case study to test my algorithm on.
>>=
> In the paper, it's mentioned that "During training, each agent is
>>> eva=
luated on a full episode (capped at 20k frames), which can include
>>> mult=
iple lives and fitness is the final episode reward". Thus I think that
>>> =
I need to track the number of frames each agent is proceeding and limit its=

>>> evaluation at 20k frames ( 5k frames for my case since I'm doing k=3D4=
 frame
>>> skipping technique for some games).
>>>
>>> I was wondering if a=
nyone could tell me which environment Uber was
>>> wrapping ( -v0 or -v4, d=
oing frame skipping or not) and also for the
>>> reward, are they just pick=
ing the last reward as the fitness score or
>>> calculating the accumulated=
 reward or doing some reward clipping.
>>>
>>> Thank you,
>>>
>>>
>> 
>>
>
=
>

--0000000000001c65da056dbba6d6

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

  =
    <p></p><div dir=3D"ltr">Hi Rihab,<div><br></div><div>Feel free to reach=
 out with any questions, we are glad people are interested on the paper and=
 reproducing it's results.</div><div>We are using NoFrameskip-v4. We fo=
llow the same preprocessing steps as other methods (Example: <a href=3D"htt=
ps://github.com/openai/baselines/blob/master/baselines/common/atari_wrapper=
s.py" target=3D"_blank">https://github.com/openai/base<wbr>lines/blob/maste=
r/baselines/<wbr>common/atari_wrappers.py</a>). We use the accumulated rewa=
rd (no discount factor, no clipping).<br></div><div>You are right on the 20=
k frames limit as it translates to 5k timesteps after the frame skips.</div=
><div><br></div><div>Best regard,</div><div>Felipe<br></div></div><div><div=
 class=3D"m_3569974043165448771h5"><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br><div clas=
s=3D"gmail_quote">On Tue, May 29, 2018 at 1:59 AM, Rihab Gorsane <a href=3D=
"mailto:rihab.gorsane@..." target=3D"_blank">rihab.gorsane@ensi-uma=
.tn</a> [neat] <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com=
" target=3D"_blank">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquo=
te class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"border-left:1px #ccc solid">


<u></u>


=

<div i=
d=3D"m_3569974043165448771m_1699904520117080958m_-173617515912917024ygrp-ml=
msg">

58m_-173617515912917024ygrp-text">
      
      
      <p></p><div dir=3D"l=
tr"><div>Hi all, <br></div><div><br></div><div>I've begun reproducing t=
he DeepNeuroevolution paper in Pytorch. I've considered only the Atari =
case study to test my algorithm on.=C2=A0</div><div>In the paper, it's =
mentioned that "During training, each agent is evaluated on a full epi=
sode (capped at 20k frames), which can include multiple lives and fitness i=
s the final episode reward". Thus I think that I need to track the num=
ber of frames each agent is proceeding and limit its evaluation at 20k fram=
es ( 5k frames for my case since I'm doing k=3D4 frame skipping techniq=
ue for some games). <br></div><div><br></div><div>I was wondering if anyone=
 could tell me which environment Uber was wrapping ( -v0 or -v4, doing fram=
e skipping or not) and also for the reward, are they just picking the last =
reward as the fitness score or calculating the accumulated reward or doing =
some reward clipping.</div><div><br></div><div>Thank you,<br></div></div>
<=
p></p>

    </div>
     

    
    <div style=3D"color:#fff;height:0"></div=
>


</div>



  






</div></div></blockquote></div><br></div>
</div></di=
v><p></p>

    </div>
     

    
    <div style=3D"color:#fff;height:0"></=
div>


</div>



  






</blockquote></div><br></div>
</div></div></block=
quote></div><br></div>
